channel.title: Bloomberg Technology

item.title: Canada’s Digital Services Tax Stays in Place Despite G-7 Deal
item.description: Canada is proceeding with its digital services tax on technology companies such as Meta Platforms Inc. despite a Group of Seven agreement that resulted in removing the Section 899 “revenge tax” proposal from US President Donald Trump’s tax bill.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Shin

media:content.media:description: Parliament Hill in Ottawa.

item.title: Crusoe, Redwood Partner on Data Center Powered by Used Batteries
item.description: It’s the world largest deployment of batteries on their second life and shows the lengths cloud operators are going to find power.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Ma, Edward Ludlow

media:content.media:description: Batteries on-site at a data center on Redwood Materials’ campus in Sparks, Nevada.

item.title: Porn-Site Age Verification Law Upheld by US Supreme Court
item.description: The US Supreme Court upheld a Texas law that requires porn sites to verify user age, rejecting arguments that the measure violates the speech rights of adults by requiring them to submit identification online.
item.dc:creator: Greg Stohr

media:content.media:description: The US Supreme Court in Washington, DC.

item.title: Apple, Google Told DeepSeek App Is Illegal in Germany
item.description: Apple Inc. and Google’s Android have been warned by a top German privacy regulator that the Chinese AI service DeepSeek, available on their app stores, constitutes illegal content because it exposes users’ data to Chinese authorities.
item.dc:creator: Karin Matussek

media:content.media:description: The DeepSeek app.

item.title: Supreme Court Upholds $8.6 Billion FCC Telecom Subsidy Fund
item.description: The US Supreme Court upheld the $8.6 billion Universal Service Fund, the annual slate of subsidies that helps cover the cost of telecom services for low-income people, rural residents, schools and libraries.
item.dc:creator: Greg Stohr

media:content.media:description: The US Supreme Court in Washington, DC. Photographer: Stefani Reynolds/Bloomberg

item.title: Argentine Fintech tapi Buys Mastercard Unit in Mexico Expansion
item.description: Argentine payments services startup tapi has acquired the bill payment and cash-handling operations of Mastercard’s Arcus in Mexico, part of a bid to double-down on Latin America’s second-largest economy.
item.dc:creator: Maria Clara Cobo

media:content.media:description: Tapi’s co-founders Kevin Litvin, left, Tomas Mindlin and Nicolas Andriano. Source: Tapi

item.title: Macquarie-Owned Fiber Provider Taps Debt Advisors Amid Cash Burn
item.description: UK broadband provider KCOM Group Limited and its lenders are gearing up for debt talks as the business owned by Macquarie burns through cash.
item.dc:creator: Giulia Morpurgo, Jamie Nimmo

media:content.media:description: Fiber optic cables

item.title: Alibaba Unveils Latest AI Service for Images in Push for Users
item.description: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. unveiled a new iteration of its artificial-intelligence technology that will make it easier for users to generate and modify images from texts and visuals, as the Chinese e-commerce giant continues its aggressive push into AI.
item.dc:creator: Luz Ding

media:content.media:description: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. headquarters in Hangzhou, China.

item.title: Nvidia Breakout Puts $4 Trillion Market Value Within Reach
item.description: Two years after Nvidia Corp. made history by becoming the first chipmaker to achieve a $1 trillion market capitalization, an even more remarkable milestone is within its grasp: becoming the first company to reach $4 trillion.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Vlastelica

media:content.media:description: Jensen Huang, co-founder and chief executive officer of Nvidia Corp., speaks during the 2025 CES event in Las Vegas, Nevada, US, on Monday, Jan. 6, 2025. Huang announced a raft of new chips, software and services, aiming to stay at the forefront of artificial intelligence computing.

item.title: Worldline’s Woes Deepen as Belgium Opens Probe Into Payment Firm
item.description: Worldline SA has long claimed to have cleaned up its payments business. Now, regulators and investors are testing that narrative after fresh allegations it overlooked fraud among high-risk clients.
item.dc:creator: Peter Chapman, Lyubov Pronina, Jonas Ekblom

media:content.media:description: The Worldline SA office building in the La Defense business district in Paris, France, on Thursday, June 26, 2025. Worldline shares cratered on Wednesday, wiping out around €500 million ($580 million) of market value on reports that the company allegedly covered up fraud by some of its customers.

item.title: Masayoshi Son Hints at Succession Plan While Chasing AI Ambition
item.description: Masayoshi Son acknowledged the outlines of a succession plan at SoftBank Group Corp., addressing what may be investors’ single biggest concern regarding the long-term future of the Japanese company.
item.dc:creator: Min Jeong Lee

media:content.media:description: Masayoshi Son during the company's annual general meeting on June 27. Photographer: Toru Hanai/Bloomberg

item.title: PwC’s AI Chief Says Firm Has Cut Prices as Tech Saves Staff Time
item.description: PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP, one of the world’s largest professional advisory firms, has cut prices for some services as clients raised the fact that the consultancy is using artificial intelligence to complete its work quicker.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Davalos, Brody Ford

media:content.media:description: PwC branding.

item.title: China Investors Ready Capital to Hunt Next DeepSeek
item.description: Welcome to Tech In Depth, our daily newsletter about the business of tech from Bloomberg’s journalists around the world. Today, Annabelle Droulers recounts her interviews with China-focused VC managers and what they’re looking for in the latter half of this year.
item.dc:creator: Annabelle Droulers

item.title: China’s $50 Billion Chip Fund Switches Tack to Fight US Curbs
item.description: China’s main chip investment fund is planning to focus on the country’s key shortcomings in sectors like lithography and semiconductor design software, adjusting its approach to better overcome US efforts to stop its technological advances.
item.dc:creator: Yuan Gao, Dong Cao

media:content.media:description: Semiconductor wafers.

item.title: RTL Agrees to Buy Sky Deutschland, Expanding Pay TV Base
item.description: RTL Group agreed to buy Comcast Corp.’s Sky Deutschland for an upfront price of €150 million ($176 million) in the TV provider’s biggest-ever deal as it looks for ways to add new revenue streams.
item.dc:creator: Benoit Berthelot

media:content.media:description: A sign at Sky Deutschland headquarters in Unterfoehring, Germany.

item.title: Allianz GI, Keppel Join Princeton Digital’s $400 Million Loan
item.description: Private credit funds Allianz Global Investors and Keppel Credit will come in as lenders for data center operator Princeton Digital Group’s $400 million private credit loan, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Megawati Wijaya

item.title: Heat Wave Threatens European Crops and Power Systems
item.description: A heat wave will bake western Europe in conditions as much as 10C above the norm in the coming days, threatening harvests, stressing power systems and triggering health alerts.
item.dc:creator: Joe Wertz

media:content.media:description: A tourist shields themselves from the sun during a heatwave in Seville.

item.title: Babbel Names New CEO for AI Age, Says IPO Is Off the Table
item.description: Babbel’s new chief executive officer said he’s focused on expanding the company’s language-learning product to include emerging artificial intelligence tools, and he doesn’t intend to revive its initial public offering.
item.dc:creator: Laura Avetisyan

media:content.media:description: KIEV, UKRAINE - 2020/06/11: In this photo illustration e-commerce Babbel logo is seen displayed on a smartphone. (Photo Illustration by Igor Golovniov/SOPA Images/LightRocket via Getty Images)

item.title: Kakaopay Sinks 17% as Authorities Flag Risks Tied to Stablecoin
item.description: Shares of South Korea’s Kakaopay Corp., which have recently surged on investor excitement over its possible stablecoin foray, dropped as much as 17% as trading resumed after a one-day halt.
item.dc:creator: Sangmi Cha

item.title: China’s ‘Revenge on Gold Diggers’ Video Game Fuels Sexism Debate
item.description: One of China’s best-selling new games has renewed a debate around sensitive gender issues in a country grappling with plunging marriage rates.
item.dc:creator: Vlad Savov, Zheping Huang

media:content.media:description: Gamers Photographer: James MacDonald/Bloomberg

item.title: Alibaba Elevates E-Commerce Chief, Shrinks Key Leadership Body
item.description: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. elevated e-commerce head Jiang Fan while trimming the members of a longstanding leadership body, as the Chinese tech giant pivots toward AI and overseas expansion.
item.dc:creator: Mark Anderson, Claire Che

media:content.media:description: Jiang Fan Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: Walmart-Backed Flipkart Turns to Videos and Livestream to Woo Indian Online Shoppers
item.description: Flipkart India Pvt., the e-commerce giant owned by Walmart Inc., is using social videos and livestreams to convert young consumers spending a lot of time on their smartphones into loyal customers.
item.dc:creator: Satviki Sanjay

media:content.media:description: A Flipkart fulfilment center in Malur, Karnataka, India. Photographer: Abhishek Chinnappa/Getty Images

item.title: Xiaomi Shares Surge After New SUV Gets 289,000 Orders in an Hour
item.description: Xiaomi Corp.’s shares rose 8% to a record high after the smartphone maker drew strong initial orders for a $35,000 sport utility vehicle intended to compete with Tesla Inc.’s Model Y in China.
item.dc:creator: Linda Lew, Jessica Sui

media:content.media:description: A Xiaomi Corp. YU7 electric SUV at one of the company's stores in Shanghai.

item.title: Tokyo Electron Shrugs Off Fears of Chinese Rivals Catching Up
item.description: Tokyo Electron Ltd. is on course to widen its lead against Chinese chip tool makers despite the billions of dollars Beijing is mobilizing to catch up, according to the Japanese company’s chief.
item.dc:creator: Takashi Mochizuki, Shery Ahn

media:content.media:description: Toshiki Kawai Photographer: Shoko Takayasu/Bloomberg

item.title: Palantir Embraces Nuclear Power With $100 Million Startup Deal
item.description: The US will need more nuclear power as it enters into greater competition with China, said Mike Gallagher, head of defense at Palantir Technologies Inc.
item.dc:creator: Miquela Thornton

media:content.media:description: Palantir Technologies Inc. Bloomberg

item.title: Uber in Talks With Kalanick to Fund Pony.AI Bid, NYT Says
item.description: Uber Technologies Inc. is in talks with founder Travis Kalanick to help fund his acquisition of the US arm of Chinese self-driving firm Pony AI Inc., the New York Times reported. Shares of both companies jumped in Thursday trading.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Lung

media:content.media:description: Travis Kalanick Photographer: Zak Bennett/Bloomberg

item.title: Google Nabs Oracle’s Cloud CFO to Lead Cloud Finance
item.description: Alphabet Inc. has plucked its new cloud finance chief from Oracle Corp., deepening a potential rivalry in the industry.
item.dc:creator: Brody Ford, Davey Alba

item.title: Micron HBM Sales Surge, Palantir’s Stock Keeps Climbing | Bloomberg Tech 6/26/2025
item.description: Bloomberg’s Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow discuss Micron’s earnings as its sales surge in its high-bandwidth memory business. Plus, Managing Director of Baird Ted Mortonson discusses opportunities in the defense tech space. Chinese tech giant Xiaomi also says it received more than 200,000 pre-orders for its first electric SUV. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: How Telegram Became a Magnet for Extremists and Crime: QuickTake
item.description: Messaging service Telegram is one of the most downloaded apps worldwide. Its private chat setting has made it a free space for open discussion in countries with authoritarian regimes. But a relatively light-touch approach to content moderation on Telegram is frustrating governments trying to stop criminal activities and the spread of misinformation that can destabilize societies.
item.dc:creator: Jeff Stone, Eleanor Thornber

media:content.media:description: Pavel Durov Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

item.title: Apple’s App Store Gets Makeover in Move to Avoid EU Fines
item.description: Apple Inc. has offered to overhaul its App Store to appease European Union antitrust watchdogs who issued an ultimatum after doling out a €500 million ($580 million) fine.
item.dc:creator: Samuel Stolton, Josh Sisco

media:content.media:description: The Apple App Store app on a laptop arranged in New York, US, on Tuesday, June 25, 2024. Apple Inc. risks billions of euros of new fines over its App Store rules as European Union antitrust regulators escalated a growing conflict over rules that strike at the heart of the iPhone makers business model. Photographer: Gabby Jones/Bloomberg
